Fig. 3a Fig. 4 Conversion of methanol (A), acetic acid (B), phenol (C), and 4-methylcatechol (D) over Pt/AC ( Image 5 ), NiCo/ZrO2 ( ), NiCu/γ-Al2O3 ( Image 2 ), and NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 ( Image 6 ). The aqueous phase reforming of methanol, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol was studied to evaluate the potential of using process water from hydrothermal liquefaction of black liquor for hydrogen production. Various catalysts, including Cu- or Co-doped nickel and commercial Pt/AC, were tested under plug-flow conditions (230 °C, 32 bar). The platinum catalyst showed superior stability, maintaining high conversion with methanol and acetic acid. However, it showed no activity with phenol and deactivated rapidly when exposed to 4-methylcatechol. Doped nickel catalysts experienced severe deactivation, particularly with acetic acid and phenolic compounds. While nickel catalyst deactivated in the presence of acetic acid, Pt showed stable conversion but favored decarboxylation reaction. APR of methanol primarily produced H2 and CO2, with NiCu/γ-Al2O3 being the most selective for H2. Co-doped nickel favored hydrogenation, forming CH4 and thus reducing H2 yield. APR of phenol and 4-methylcatechol produced H2, CO2, and hydrodeoxygenated or hydrogenated liquid products. Graphical Abstract Keywords APR Black liquor Hydrogen Copper Cobalt Deactivation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive use of resources, increasing world population, and our disposable lifestyle cause a significant strain on the waste management sector. Therefore, it is crucial to develop sustainable waste reuse practices to address this challenge. Biorefineries play a key role in this initiative, as they can convert materials like biomass, sewage sludge, or animal manure into valuable products such as biofuels, chemicals, and energy. One example of such biorefinery processes is hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL), where biomass is processed with water under sub- or supercritical conditions to produce a complex mixture of biofuels called biocrude. However, HTL generates a significant amount of aqueous phase containing dissolved organic carbon compounds at concentrations ranging from 3 to 10 wt% [1–4]. Managing these aqueous streams is costly, and after purification, most of the water ends up discarded. One potential solution to increase circularity is recycling the water phase with conventional technologies such as steam reforming (SR), which can be used to convert and reuse dissolved carbon compounds. As a downside, SR is highly energy-intensive and requires high temperatures (500 – 800 °C, feed dependent), making it necessary to vaporize the water in the feed and couple it with another organic stream to achieve a stream with a steam-to-carbon ratio of 1:3 [5]. A more energy and cost-efficient solution would be to apply catalytic aqueous-phase reforming (APR), a promising approach that enables direct conversion of the diluted aqueous effluent in a liquid phase. Compared with steam reforming, APR occurs at milder temperatures (220 – 270 °C) and elevated pressures (25 – 50 bar) to maintain the feed in the liquid phase, thus avoiding separation of water before treating the organics. The process was first introduced by the group of Dumesic, demonstrating the potential of APR technology for many oxygenated molecules to produce hydrogen-rich gas [6], making such process a potential source of renewable H2 and supporting the transition to sustainable energy systems, while simultaneously reducing waste from currently unutilized process streams. The composition of the aqueous phase from HTL varies depending on the source of biomass. For example, the HTL aqueous phase from algae feedstock comprises nitrogenous compounds, organic acids (acetic, propionic, and butanoic acids), and oxygenated compounds produced from the degradation of carbohydrates [3]. Another more frequently studied HTL feedstock is lignocellulosic biomass [2,4,7,8]. Recently, Pola et al. [7] studied the HTL of Kraft black liquor (BL), which is an aqueous solution of hemicellulose residues and cooking alkaline salt used in the process. It is composed of simple alcohols (methanol, ethanol), phenolic compounds, and organic acids (formic acid, acetic acid, glycolic acid) for a total organic concentration of ∼3 wt%. A similar composition had been previously reported by Nguyen et al. [8], including a more detailed identification of the dissolved aromatic compounds (phenols, cresols, and catechols). Due to their oxygenated nature and moderate carbon content, BL-based process waters have great potential to be used in the APR reaction. In APR conditions, various reactions occur. The overall aqueous-phase reforming to hydrogen is represented by Eq. 1, in which oxygenated molecules react to form carbon monoxide and hydrogen through bond cleavage. Effective catalysts should also facilitate the Water-Gas-Shift (WGS) reaction (Eq. 2) to generate CO2 and more H2. Undesirable side reactions in the focus of the current study include methanation (Eq. 3) and alkane formation through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (Eq. 4), as they deplete the desired product, hydrogen, even though they contribute to the water purification and can also be considered valuable compound. (1) Reforming : C n H 2 y O n → nCO + y H 2 (2) WGS : CO + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + H 2 (3) Methanation : C O n + ( 2 + n ) H 2 ↔ C H 4 + n H 2 O (4) Fischer − Tropsch : nCO + ( 2 n + 1 ) H 2 ↔ C n H ( 2 n + 2 ) + n H 2 O Both monometallic and bimetallic catalysts have been used in APR, the most common metals being platinum (Pt) and nickel (Ni) [9–15]. In addition to these, palladium (Pd), cobalt (Co), ruthenium (Ru), rhenium (Re), and rhodium (Rh) are active metals used in some studies [9,16,17]. Platinum catalysts are most often preferred for APR due to their high activity for C-C bond scission, high H2 yield, and excellent stability under APR conditions [14]. Conversely, nickel catalysts are frequently explored because of their lower cost and better availability [18]. Depending on the specific reactants and reaction conditions, nickel catalysts can exhibit comparably high activity for C-C bond cleavage [19]. However, at lower temperatures, Ni can catalyze the formation of alkanes through C-O scission followed by hydrogenation, which can reduce the hydrogen yield [16]. To enhance hydrogen selectivity in APR reactions, addition of catalyst dopants, such as cobalt and copper (Cu), into the nickel matrix has been proven beneficial [12,20]. Coronado et al. [12] investigated several doped and un-doped nickel catalysts supported on mixed oxide materials for the APR of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis water alcohols and found the bimetallic catalyst to have great potential in terms of H2 selectivity. Similar observations have been made also for other substrates aside alcohols. For example, incorporating copper into nickel supported on hydrotalcite-type materials has been shown to reduce methane formation in the APR of glycerol [21]. The applied reaction conditions during APR create a challenging environment for catalysts, often leading to their deactivation. In APR, several mechanisms can contribute to this deactivation, including metal leaching, catalyst coking, sintering, and metal re-oxidation [20]. In fact, catalyst stability remains a primary issue in the commercialization of this technology; however, this can be partially addressed by careful selection of appropriate materials for the catalyst systems. To improve stability, active metals are typically anchored on catalyst supports. In the literature, the most studied supports in APR are alumina (Al2O3), ceria (CeO2), silica (SiO2), titania (TiO2), zirconia (ZrO2), and magnesia (MgO) [12,13,15,16,22]. Generally, oxide supports are commonly preferred in reforming as they favor activation of the water molecules, which is required for the WGS reaction (converting CO to CO2) and enhances H2 yield [23–25]. However, for many applications, SiO2 and MgO are found to be unstable in APR conditions [16,22]. On the other hand, zirconia and certain mixed oxides – particularly those including lanthanum (La), and ceria – are among the few oxides that can withstand the harsh conditions of APR [13]. In particular, mixed oxides of ceria and zirconia offer several advantages over pure oxides, including enhanced stability, improved resistance to catalyst coking, and high oxygen storage capacity [26]. Additionally, alumina is one of the most studied supports in APR-related literature, despite its limited morphological stability under hydrothermal conditions, which typically cause a phase change of γ-alumina to boehmite [27–29]. Along with metal oxides, carbon-based supports, including activated carbon, carbon black, and carbon nanotubes, have been studied for APR reactions due to their excellent physico-chemical stability in hot compressed water [14,18,20,30−32]. Kaya et al. [32] prepared and studied different types of carbon-supported Pt catalysts for APR of lignocellulosic biomass hydrolysate. In the study, activated carbon was reported to have the highest gas production, while graphene oxide was the most selective for hydrogen. Justicia et al. [30], on the other hand, demonstrated a high stability and activity of Pt/carbon black in the bio-oil aqueous fraction. Other metals, including Pt, have been used with carbon support materials. For example, Haasterecht et al. [14] studied APR of ethylene glycol using CNF as support and using either Cu, Co, Ni, or Pt as the active metal. Platinum was found to have the highest hydrogen selectivity, followed by copper, cobalt, and nickel in that order. Since the introduction of APR technology in 2002, most literature has focused on model compounds, especially alcohols with a carbon-to-oxygen ratio of 1:1, such as methanol, sugar alcohols, sugar hydrolysate, and glycerol [6,10,11,13,33–36]. Other substrates, including ethanol, propanols, butanol, acetic acid, furfural, and hydroxy acetone, have also been studied to some extent [12,27,30,37–39]. However, there is still limited research on APR of more stable molecules, like phenolic compounds [37,40–42], possibly due to the challenge of breaking the aromatic structure under APR conditions. Thus, broadening the scope to include oxygenated aromatic compounds would enable several possibilities for new APR raw materials and catalyst development. This study investigated the APR of typical compounds derived from hydrothermal liquefaction of black liquor. Methanol, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol were selected as representative chemicals based on their prevalence in real HTL aqueous phase [4,7,8]. The experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed plug-flow reactor over four supported metal catalysts: NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2, NiCu/γ-Al2O3, NiCo/ZrO2, and Pt/AC. Due to limited existing literature on the APR of phenolic compounds, catalyst compositions that have shown promise with more frequently studied compounds were chosen for the present work. In particular, the nickel catalysts were selected according to our previous research on APR of light alcohols [9,23] and the hydrophilic fraction of bio-oil [10,12,37]. Alumina was chosen as one of the benchmark supports for this work, as it is very often used in APR literature and shows good performance in some applications [10,43]. Furthermore, as noble metals are often studied for APR, a commercial platinum catalyst was included as a reference material. Fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by TEM, elemental analysis, ICP-OES, XRD, and N2 physisorption. To develop an efficient catalyst for reactions with real aqueous effluents, it is vital to evaluate the behavior of the same catalysts with commonly tested substrates like methanol and acetic acid, as well as scarcely studied phenolic compounds. This provides a wider perspective on how individual compounds influence catalyst stability and activity, thus aiding in the selection of the best candidate and laying the groundwork for future studies on more complex mixtures. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials and chemicals The chemicals used in the study were methanol (99.9 % purity), acetic acid (100 % purity), phenol (99 % purity), and 4-methylcatechol (98 % purity), all purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Each model compound solution only contained one carbon compound, and these mixtures were prepared using deionized water from the laboratory. The concentration of oxygenates was 5 wt% (50 g/L), selected to mimic the total concentration of carbon in the aqueous effluents from the HTL of black liquor. Hydrogen was used for catalyst reduction, and nitrogen was used for reactor purging, and as an internal standard; both gases were supplied by Woikoski with 99.999 % purity. The nickel catalysts were prepared from different oxide supports and promoters. Nickel (Ni(NO3)2 • 6H2O, > 99 %), cobalt (Co(NO3)2) • 6H2O, 98 %), and copper nitrates (Cu(NO3)2 • 3H2O, 103 %) were used as precursors and were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. γ-Al2O3 (500 µm, Accusphere®) and monoclinic ZrO2 (500 µm, Accusphere®) were supplied by Saint-Gobain and used as received. Ceria-zirconia (25 % CeO2-75 % ZrO2) support was provided by MEL Chemicals as a fine powder. Prior to catalyst preparations, the ceria-zirconia was calcined at 450 °C for 10 h, followed by pelletizing, crushing, and sieving into particles within the range of 200–300 µm as was done in our previous work [9]. The commercial 5 wt% Pt/AC catalyst was provided by Sigma Aldrich in powder form. Due to its small particle size (19 µm), the Pt catalyst was mixed with inert silicon carbide (150–210 µm) in a 1:1 vol ratio to prevent reactor blockage. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts, namely 10 %Ni-5 %Cu/CeO2-ZrO2, 10 %Ni-10 %Cu/γ-Al2O3, and 10 %Ni-5 %Co/ZrO2 were synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation method (IWI) as previously reported by Coronado et al. [12]. The selection of the IWI technique was based on its ability to provide precise control over the active metal loadings and to compare the results with our previous work. The preparation method commenced with the drying of the catalyst supports in a vacuum (<30 mbar) at 80 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, an aqueous solution of Ni nitrate and either Co or Cu nitrate was impregnated onto the support in a vacuum (<30 mbar). Following this, the catalyst was left to rest at room temperature overnight in a sealed flask. The realized amounts of metal salt precursors for each catalyst are provided in Supplementary material (Table S1). The following day, the catalyst was dried in using rotary evaporator until the catalyst moved freely in the flask. A vacuum of 50 mbar and water bath temperature of 80 °C was applied in the drying step. Finally, the catalysts were calcined in flowing air of 300 cm3/min at 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. For clarity, the resulting catalysts will henceforth be denoted as NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2, NiCu/γ-Al2O3, and NiCo/ZrO2, referred to as the fresh catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by nitrogen adsorption and desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), and elemental analysis to determine carbon content. XRD was also performed for the reduced catalyst samples. Before XRD analysis, the catalyst reduction was performed ex-situ with 3 % H2 in N2 (150 Ncm3/min) at 450 °C. Nitrogen physisorption was conducted using Micromeritic 3Flex equipment. The catalyst supports and fresh catalysts were degassed in vacuum (50 mTorr) for 19 h at 200 °C. The spent catalyst sampled were degassed in a vacuum of 50 mTorr and at a temperature of 120 °C for 5 h to prevent detachment of carbonaceous species from the catalyst surface. For spent carbon-supported catalysts, which typically can adsorb a lot of water into their microporous structure, the degassing time was extended to overnight. Specific surface areas of the samples were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the average pore diameter and the average pore volume were determined based on the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) desorption isotherms. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a probe corrected JEOL JEM-ARM200F (NeoARM) microscope equipped with a cold field emission gun operated at 200 keV and a OneView CMOS camera (IS-version; Gatan). It was also used for STEM and EDX investigations, for which a JEOL EDX detector “Centurio 100” was used to measure the elemental composition. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted with Panalytical X ´ pert Powder with Cu Kα1 radiation (45 kV and 40 mA) with continuous scanning from 5° to 120° 2θ with step size of 0.0131°. Analysis was performed by using Panalytical HighScore Plus 4.5 software and ICDD PDF-5 + 2025 database. The mean crystallite size (τ) of reduced catalyst particles was calculated with the Scherrer equation (Eq. 5). The wavelength (λ) of Cu K-α applied in the Scherrer equation was 1.541874 Å and the crystallite shape factor (K) was 0.9. (5) τ = Kλ β τ cos θ The metal loadings, Co, Cu, and Ni were analyzed using ICP-OES (5110 SVDV, Agilent Technologies). 200 mg of catalyst sample was dissolved with microwave-assisted acid digestion in the presence of concentrated HNO3 and HCl solutions at a temperature of 180 °C and were further diluted with 1 % nitric acid solution (EMPLURA®). Total relative error of the analysis was calculated to be ± 5 %. Carbon content was analyzed for the fresh and spent catalysts with LECO CHN 828 analyzer by burning the sample with pure oxygen at 950 °C. The samples were dried overnight at 105 °C before analysis. Experimental error for carbon analysis was ± 1 wt%, which was determined from three independent runs for each catalyst. 2.4 Reactor system and procedure The experimental reactor setup is illustrated in the scheme presented in Fig. 1. The APR of the model compound solutions was studied in a stainless-steel tubular reactor with an 8 mm inner diameter and a total length of 400 mm. In each experiment, 1.5 g of a catalyst was positioned in the middle of the reactor, secured by a metal grate and a thin layer of quartz wool. Prior to the reforming experiments, the nickel catalysts underwent in situ reduction at 450 °C and 1 bar for 2 h, employing a flow of H2:N2 (1:1 molar ratio) at a rate of 150 Ncm3/min. The platinum catalysts were reduced at 250 °C while maintaining other operational parameters identical to those for nickel. Subsequent to reduction, the catalyst bed temperature was lowered to the desired reaction temperature of 230 °C in pure N2. The reactor was then pressurized to 32 bar using an Equilibar® back-pressure regulator. The selection of the reaction temperature and pressure was based on the gas-liquid equilibria to maintain the feed near bubble point conditions and to facilitate comparison with existing literature. Before introducing the reactant solution into the reactor, the system was purged with N2 for a minimum of 2 h to remove any excess H2 from the reduction step. During purging, the outlet gas composition was monitored using a micro-GC. Once no H2 was detected in the outlet gas, the reaction was initiated by commencing the liquid feed with an HPLC pump, delivering the model solution through the reactor. The liquid flow rate was held constant at 2 cm3/min (WHSV= 4 h−1) in each experiment and was fed to the reactor through a heated line (200 °C). The mean residence time in the reactor, given the flow rate used, corresponds to 10 min. Nitrogen was co-fed with the liquid feed at a flow rate of 150 Ncm3/min (equivalent to 2.3 cm3/min at 32 bar) and was utilized as an internal standard and as a sweep gas to aid in purging the gas product. The time-on-stream (TOS) for all catalysts was 180 min, commencing when the reaction conditions were stabilized. Following the experiments, the system was gradually cooled down overnight in a nitrogen flow, and the dried catalyst was extracted from the reactor. 2.5 Product analysis Gaseous products were analysed online using Agilent 490 Micro GC with four channel cabinet that included CP-Molsieve 5 A, CP-PoraPlot U, CP-Al2O3/KCl, and CP-Sil 5CB columns with four TCDs. Argon was used as the carrier gas with CP-Molsieve 5A-column, while helium was used in all other channels. A relative error for gas analysis was accounted to be 1 % per compound calibrated. Liquid products were collected from the gas-liquid separator every 30 min and analysed offline with a Shimadzu GC-2010 Plus equipped with HP-INNOWax column (60 m x 0.25 mm×0.25 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Buta-2-nol was used as an internal standard in this analysis. The analysis program was as follows: temperature was held at 60 °C for 3 min, then increased to 230 °C with the heating rate of 10 °C/min and hold at that temperature for 30 min. Liquid analysis was subject to a relative error of 5 % per compound. 2.6 Calculations The conversion of model compound "j" was determined using Eq. 6, where "j" represents methanol, acetic acid, phenol, or 4-methylcatechol, based on the initial concentration ( c j , t = 0 ) and the measured concentration in the samples , c j , t , (i.e. constant volume approximation). The hydrogen yield was calculated using Eq. 7, accounting for the reaction stoichiometry in both reforming (Eq. 1) and WGS reactions (Eq. 2). This calculation includes the reforming ratio (RR), which represents the maximum theoretical molar ratio of H2 to CO2. Specifically, the RR is 3 for methanol, 2 for acetic acid, 2.3 for phenol, and 2.4 for 4-methylcatechol. The product yield of component "i" was determined using Eq. 8, where "i" represents products in both the gas phase and the liquid stream. The carbon balance (CB) was assessed using Eq. 9, where "C" denotes carbon-containing compounds in the feed and outlet streams, including both gaseous and liquid products as well as reactants. (6) X j % = 100 · c j , t = 0 − c j , t c j , t = 0 (7) Y H 2 % = 100 · n ̇ H 2 in the outlet n ̇ j in the feed · 1 RR (8) Y i ( % ) = 100 · m ̇ i in the outlet m ̇ j in feed (9) CB ( % ) = 100 · n ̇ C in the outlet n ̇ C in the feed 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the fresh catalysts The in-house prepared nickel catalysts (fresh) were analyzed by several characterization techniques including TEM, XRD, ICP-OES, and nitrogen adsorption-desorption. XRD analysis was also performed for the reduced nickel catalysts to compare the Ni crystal size against spent counterparts after APR experiments. The commercial Pt/AC catalyst was analyzed using N2 adsorption-desorption. The physico-chemical properties of the fresh catalysts and catalyst supports are summarized in Tables 1 and 2. Over 90 % of the targeted Ni loadings were achieved with prepared CeO2-ZrO2 and ZrO2-supported catalysts. In addition, over 84 % of the targeted promoter loadings were reached for the same catalysts. However, for the γ-Al2O3 supported catalyst, only around 81 % of the Ni and 62 % of the Cu were deposited in the preparation process. This difference was likely due to a small excess volume of deionized water (visual observation) and insufficient vacuum pressure during the metal impregnation step. The BET surface areas of the nickel catalyst supports ranged from 95 m2/g (ZrO2) to 230 m2/g (γ-Al2O3). After metal impregnations, the surface areas and pore volumes decreased for calcined catalysts, except for the NiCo/ZrO2, which had virtually the same pore volume prior to and after the introduction of active the metals. The decrease in surface area was around 32 % for ZrO2, 20 % for γ-Al2O3, and 35 % for CeO2-ZrO2-supported nickel catalyst. Additionally, the average pore diameter remained constant or slightly increased (NiCo/ZrO2) after the impregnation of Ni and the promoter. The BET surface area for the commercial Pt/AC was 915 m2/g, and the total pore volume was 0.43 cm3/g (micropore volume 0.014 cm3/g, about 3.5 % of the total pore volume). The crystalline phases of the doped Ni-catalysts were identified through XRD analysis. The XRD diffractograms (Figs. 13–15) and calculated crystal sizes of the support and reduced catalysts ( Table 3) are detailed in Section 3.3. The monoclinic phase (ICDD 04-008-7681) characteristic for ZrO2 was detected in the NiCo/ZrO2 samples, while the X-ray diffractogram of CeO2-ZrO2 exhibited main reflections specific to the tetragonal phase (ICDD 04–016–7938). Additionally, the XRD analysis revealed the presence of a cubic gamma-alumina phase in the alumina supported catalyst (ICDD 00–29–0063). Following reduction, the added metal (M) promoters, Co or Cu, were observed to exist as bimetallic NiCu and NiCo alloys. Notably, the particle size of NiM was found to be largest for NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2, ranging from 17 to 29 nm, while NiCu/γ-Al2O3 and NiCo/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited crystal size ranges of 17–18 nm and 13–21 nm, respectively. It should be noted that due to insufficient contrast, TEM analysis did not allow for a clear distinction between the active metals and support (see Fig. 2), thus resulting in the average particle size representing both the active phase and support. Specifically, the average metal particle size obtained from TEM was 6 ± 2 nm for NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2, 7 ± 4 nm for NiCu/γ-Al2O3, and 11 ± 5 nm for NiCo/ZrO2, aligning well with the calculated support crystal size from XRD, which measured 5–6 nm for CeO2-ZrO2, 3–4 nm for γ-Al2O3, and 13–14 nm for ZrO2-supported nickel catalysts. 3.2 Aqueous-phase reforming of model components Aqueous-phase reforming of methanol, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol was studied in a continuous fixed-bed plug-flow reactor using model compound mixtures with 5 wt% organic concentration. Three in-house prepared nickel catalysts and one commercial platinum catalyst were studied with each reactant under the same reaction conditions: 230 °C, 32 bar, and WHSV of 4 h−1 (see Section 2.4). The experiments were continued for three hours after the desired reaction conditions had been reached. A blank test (no catalyst) was carried out with each model compound solution to study whether any conversion and gaseous products are formed via thermal decomposition. No conversion or gaseous products were observed in these tests. In addition, experiments with pure water were done with all catalysts. In these experiments, the catalyst was first reduced at similar conditions as they were done in tests with model compound solutions. After reduction, the reactor was flushed with N2 to remove excess H2, and the water feed was initiated. Surprisingly, H2 was detected in the experiments with deionized water. The measured H2 concentrations in the outlet gas are shown in Fig. 3A. Hydrogen concentrations from APR of acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol are shown in the figure for comparison. Due to very different level of H2 formation, methanol has been plotted to separate figure ( Fig. 3B). Regarding nickel catalysts, H2 concentration up to 1.0 vol% was detected in the outlet gas with 100 % deionized water (Fig. 3A. NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2), whereas no products were seen with Pt/AC catalyst. Possible explanations for the H2 formation are desorption of submerged hydrogen from the catalyst lattice [44], or the layer oxidation of NiM(0) by water, yielding NiO and H2, which might be favored at lower pH, particularly acid that dissolves the oxidized metal. Fig. 4 shows the conversion of each model compound per tested catalyst as a function of time. The catalyst stability and, thus, conversion per time varied remarkably depending on the reactant used. In methanol APR, the platinum and the three nickel catalysts showed a stable conversion between 10–18 % throughout the three-hour experimental period. The highest conversion of 18 % in methanol experiments was detected with NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst. For experiments with acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol, all nickel catalysts deactivated rapidly within 60 min time-on-stream (TOS). Interestingly, a stable conversion of 10 % was observed with acetic acid and Pt/AC, whereas in the APR of phenolic compounds, there was a rapid deactivation or no activity at all with platinum catalyst. For 4-methylcatechol and platinum catalyst, the initial conversion was notably high, 30 %, but dropped to around 15 % after 60 min TOS. In phenol APR, no activity (no gaseous or liquid products) was seen at any stage of the experiment (Fig. S1). The subsequent sections discuss catalyst activity and product yields per tested compound in more detail. Section 3.3 delves into the stability from the perspective of a catalyst and presents the catalyst characterization results for the spent samples. 3.2.1 Methanol Methanol was selected as a representative compound from the aliphatic alcohols found in the actual water fraction of black liquor HTL. Additionally, as the selected nickel catalyst compositions have previously demonstrated good activity with the APR of methanol and other alcohols [12,13], methanol was, in this case, used also to evaluate the performance of the catalyst prepared for this study before progressing to other model compounds. Fig. 5 presents the product yields and carbon balance for each catalyst tested in APR of methanol. The product distribution is compared at TOS 180 min. In the gas phase, the main compounds were H2, CO2, and CH4, with trace amounts of CO and C2H6. Only unreacted methanol was detected in the liquid phase. The hydrogen yield ranged from ∼ 10–11 % for all studied catalysts, with the highest yield of 11.2 % observed with the Pt/AC catalyst. It should be noted that the calculation used for H2 yield considers the stoichiometry of the reforming and WGS reactions (methanol complete reforming, Eq. 10). The CO2 yield was between 12.2–13.5 % for all catalysts. The molar ratio of H2:CO2 was close to the value of 3.4 with all tested catalysts, thus aligning well with the expected reaction stoichiometry. The solubility of CO2 at studied conditions can explain the slight deviation from the predicted value in these conditions, resulting in part of the carbon dioxide going unquantified. Methanol full reforming (10) Image 7 The product distribution was similar with Cu-doped nickel and Pt catalysts, which exhibited good selectivity towards the reforming reaction, and only trace amounts of side-products (primarily alkanes) were detected in the outlet. This finding aligns with previous studies regarding the use of copper as a catalyst dopant in methanol APR [12,45]. Similar results have been reported with other reactants; for instance, Tuza et al. [21] indicated that the incorporation of copper led to a decrease in methane formation during the APR of glycerol. In contrast, Co-doped nickel seemed to favor hydrogenation reactions (Eqs. 3 and 4), resulting in a considerable amount of methane (Y(CH4)= 4 %) and a small fraction of ethane as side-products (Fig. 5). The alkane production was attributed to the C-O bond cleavage of the methanol molecule, forming CHx species that recombine with the adsorbed H atoms on the catalyst surface [19]. In addition, trace amounts of CO were detected in the gas phase (Y(CO)= 0.4 %) with NiCo/ZrO2. One hypothesis is that the Co affects the surface equilibrium and slows down the Water Gas Shift (Eq. 2) elementary steps, resulting in some CO left unreacted. On the other hand, Cu is known to have higher WGS activity (removing CO from the catalyst surface at low temperatures) compared to Ni, Pt, or Co, thus explaining the higher H2 selectivity [46]. As said, the selection of nickel catalyst compositions was based on our previous research [12,13]. It is important to note that our group has not previously tested the metal combinations NiCo/ZrO2 and NiCu/γ-Al2O3 for the APR of methanol; however, NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 has demonstrated significant activity and hydrogen yield. Therefore, it was important to compare the performance of the prepared catalysts. In terms of product selectivity, we successfully replicated the results obtained in previous studies; however, the main difference was in the activity of the prepared catalysts. For the NiCu catalyst prepared for this work, the observed methanol conversion was approximately 5 times lower (at the same WHSV of 4 h−1) than what was reported previously. Specifically, for NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2, NiCu/γ-Al2O3 (and Pt/AC), the conversion was around 10 %, whereas the highest methanol conversion of 18 % was achieved with the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst (see Fig. 4A). Similar conversion values to those we previously reported have been indicated by Goma et al. [47], which attained almost 75 % methanol conversion with WHSV of 4 h−1 at 230 °C and 32 bar using 5 wt% Ni/calcia-stabilized zirconia. Other studies have reported high methanol conversion under different reaction conditions and lower WHSV [6,28,48,49]. For instance, Cortright et al. [6] have reported over 90 % conversion with 3 wt% Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in methanol APR at 29 bar and 205 °C, but the WHSV was only 0.008 h−1. Sousa et al. [48], investigated the effect of WHSV on the activity of 5 wt% Pt/Al2O3. They found that at 230 °C and 32 bar, methanol conversion varied from 5 % to 70 %, with the lowest conversion occurring at WHSV of approximately 4 h⁻¹ and the highest at a space velocity below 1 h⁻¹. Similarly, De Vlieger et al. [28] achieved around 60 % conversion to gas with a space velocity of 1.2 h⁻¹ using 1.5 wt% Pt and 1.15–0.35 wt% Pt-Ni catalysts supported on alumina, employing very high temperatures (275 °C) and pressures (200 bar). In batch operation, methanol conversions between 6 % and 10 % have been reported [50,51]. However, it is essential to recognize the complexities associated with comparing results from different reactor types, as they may not be directly comparable. The lower activity might be associated with the crystal size of the nickel alloy, which is supported by literature suggesting that smaller particles tend to promote higher hydrogen selectivity and facilitate C-C bond breaking in APR conditions [52,53]. In the study by Stekrova et al. [13], the size of the NiO species for the monometallic Ni catalyst supported by 25 %CeO2-ZrO2 was reported to be between 11 and 13 nm, leading to a methanol conversion of 59 % (WHSV= 4 h⁻¹). In contrast, Coronado et al. [12] found that the NiCu/25 %CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst, with a nickel-copper alloy cluster size of 21 nm, achieved a methanol conversion of 38 % (WHSV= 4 h⁻¹). In our current work, the crystal sizes of the reduced NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts ranged from 17 to 29 nm, reflecting the variation between the largest and smallest crystals as determined by XRD. Conversely, the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited crystal particle sizes of 13–15 nm, which resulted in the highest conversion observed in this study. It should be noted that the particle size distribution could not be accurately verified using TEM due to the low contrast between the support and the active metals. One hypothesis is that most of the nickel clusters fall within a size range where active sites are unavailable for methanol activation, specifically for dehydrogenation and C-C bond cleavage. The conditions used during catalyst reduction can also contribute to the differences observed in the catalyst activities. In our previous studies, the catalyst reduction was conducted at 25 bar due to setup requirements, whereas in this study, it was performed at atmospheric pressure. Similar reduction temperatures, molar compositions of H2/N2, and total gas flow rates were applied in both cases. The higher pressure used in the previous work could have lowered the reduction temperature of metal oxides, enhancing the reducibility of the active metals. Additionally, the rate at which the temperature is increased during the reduction step can affect the size and distribution of metal crystals, changing interactions between the support and the metal, and thus possibly explaining the differences in activity observed between this work and prior studies [54]. 3.2.2 Acetic acid Acetic acid was chosen to represent the group of carboxylic acids of the HTL water fraction. Fig. 6 presents the yields of gaseous products and carbon balance in the APR of acetic acid for the four studied catalysts. Due to the very rapid deactivation of nickel catalysts (see Fig. 4B), the product yields were compared at the initial state of the experiment, i.e., TOS 30 min. The cause of deactivation was attributed to severe nickel and promoter leaching in the applied conditions ( Table 4). At TOS 30 min, only unreacted acetic acid was detected in the withdrawn liquid samples, whereas the composition of the gas phase varied depending on the catalyst used. Pt/AC, which also showed stable acetic acid conversion (10 %) throughout the experiment, produced mainly CH4 and CO2, with yields (mass based) of 2.6 % and 5.6 %, respectively. The hydrogen yield for the Pt catalyst was only 0.2 %, suggesting that another reaction than reforming of acetic acid (Eq. 11) prevailed. In aqueous solutions, the reforming of acetic acid can involve decarboxylation reactions, according to Eq. 12. Stoichiometry of the decarboxylation of acetic acid estimates a 1:1 molar ratio toward CH4 and CO2, compared to 1.2:1, seen in the experiment with Pt catalyst. The lower value seen in this work most likely results from the high solubility of carbon dioxide in water in the applied conditions. This observation aligned with the studies conducted by Justicia et al. [30], who investigated the activity of 3 wt% Pt/carbon black for the APR of 1 % acetic acid. Their research demonstrated the formation of CO2 and CH4 during batch operation with varying reaction times. Similar observations have been made by others with different catalyst supports [38,55,56]. For example, Pipitone et al. [56] tested commercial 5 wt% Pt/Al2O3 for acetic acid APR. In their work, a 1:1 ratio of methane to carbon dioxide was detected in the gas phase, with an acetic acid conversion of approximately 22 % at 230 °C. In contrast to our study, the APR experiments were performed under batch reaction conditions. Full reforming of acetic acid (11) Image 8 Acetic acid decarboxylation (12) Image 9 In the case of nickel catalysts, the hydrogen yields were low, reaching a maximum of 1.5 % before the catalyst deactivation. At a time-on-stream of 30 min, the highest hydrogen yield (Y(H2)) of 1.5 was obtained with the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst. Surprisingly, only hydrogen was produced with Cu-doped catalysts, with Y(H2) values of 1.1 % for NiCu/γ-Al2O3 and 1.0 % for NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2. This was attributed to the release of hydrogen from the catalyst surface at the start of the experiment (see Fig. 3A), rather than from the reforming of acetic acid. This non-reaction-based hydrogen also contributed to the higher H2 yield compared to CO2 formation with the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst. For Co-doped nickel, the H2 yield compared to the production of CO2 was 9:1, significantly deviating from the theoretical value of 2:1 (Eq. 11). Arandia et al. [37] tested three monometallic nickel catalysts for APR of 10 wt% acetic acid solution. The H2 yields and activity of the catalyst they tested were in a similar range as were reported in this work. However, their results were obtained after 3 h TOS, while our findings reflect a TOS of only 30 min due to catalyst deactivation. Arandia et al. also noted catalyst deactivation by leaching, while the extent of the metal dissolution was lower than reported in this work. The results obtained in this work are somewhat contradictory, as the addition of dopants (i.e., alloying) is generally expected to enhance catalyst stability [57]. One possible explanation for this rather unexpected outcome could be related to the catalyst preparation or reduction process. In the study of Arandia et al., a reduction pressure of 25 bar was used due to equipment-related issues, whereas in this work, atmospheric conditions were applied. The higher reduction pressure could increase the reducibility and dispersion of the active metals, which could induce higher support-metal interactions and, consequently, better catalyst stability [54]. Overall, in the experiments of nickel catalysts for the aqueous phase reforming of acetic acid, rapid deactivation and non-reaction-based hydrogen in the gas phase obscured the catalyst characteristics, making it challenging to draw conclusions about the prevailing reactions. Additionally, with the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst, methane was formed to a similar extent as CO2, further complicating the reaction network by introducing the possibility of methane formation under acidic conditions through methanation (Eq. 3) and decarboxylation (Eq. 12). 3.2.3 Phenol Phenol was selected as one of the aromatic compounds due to its prevalence in HTL waters that originate from lignocellulosic biomass. The product composition in phenol APR was evaluated at TOS 30 min due to rapid catalyst deactivation. The platinum catalyst showed no activity meaning no reaction products were detected under the tested conditions at any stage of the experiment. For the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst, H2 and CO2 were detected in the gas phase, while for Cu-doped catalysts, hydrogen was the only gaseous product ( Fig. 7). In the liquid stream, small amounts of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol, along with non-converted phenol, were detected with all nickel catalysts with varying concentrations (refer to Fig. 8). The product yields with phenol were low, less than 1 %, even before catalyst deactivation. For NiCo/ZrO2, hydrogen and carbon dioxide yields were 0.9 % and 0.6 %, respectively. The liquid product yield for NiCo/ZrO2 was 0.4 %. The H2 yield for the two Cu-doped catalysts ranged from 0.2–0.3 %, and the liquid product yield was less than 0.2 %. It should be noted that in the case of nickel catalysts, the hydrogen yield at TOS 30 min was most likely affected by the background H2 that is released from the catalyst surface at the beginning of the reaction, as seen in Fig. 3A, with deionized water. The effect is clearer with Cu-doped catalysts, which results in mostly hydrogen being detected in the gas phase. This also partly explains why the activity with the Cu-doped Ni-catalysts decreases rapidly after such a short time period: after atomic hydrogen (that is desorbed from the catalyst surface) is consumed by hydrogenation reactions, conversion of the reactant also decreases with Cu-doped nickel catalysts. According to this, the Cu-doped nickel catalysts are most likely active for hydrogenation reactions and incapable of reforming phenol to form H2, which would enable the parallel reactions to form liquid products. Conversely, the use of cobalt as a catalyst dopant seems to promote the hydrogenation and the parallel reforming of phenol seen as constant formation of H2 and CO2, and also the two liquid products. The complete reforming of phenol can be described by Eq. 13. According to the reaction stoichiometry, the expected reforming ratio of H2 to CO2 is around 2.3 (14 mol H2 to 6 mol CO2). NiCo/ZrO2 exhibited a reforming ratio close to the theoretical value (molar ratio of H2/CO2∼2) and was likely influenced by the hydrogenation reactions, which led to the production of cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol at the expense of hydrogen production (Eq. 14). Previous research on the hydrogenation of phenol suggested the reaction to take place in a sequential manner. The benzene ring of phenol is first partially hydrogenated to form an enol, which is unstable and isomerizes rapidly to form cyclohexanone; cyclohexanone which is an intermediate product, can be further hydrogenated to cyclohexanol [58–60]. Full reforming of phenol (13) Image 10 Phenol hydrogenation (14) Image 11 Regarding conversion, the NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst had the highest initial conversion of 7 %, and a maximum of 10 % was reached at TOS 60 min. Shortly after, the phenol conversion drops below 2 % and stays at that level for the rest of the experiment. For NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 and NiCu/γ-Al2O3, there was a fluctuation in the conversion levels, varying from 0.5 % to 5 % over time. However, after 30 min, no products were detected in the withdrawn samples, meaning other reactions occurred. Further analysis of the liquid samples with GC-MS revealed a dimer, 2-phenylphenol, suggesting to phenol oligomerization (Fig. S2). Additional methods are required to identify other possibly polymerized compounds, as in this case, GC-MS is somewhat limited for large molecular weight compounds due to long eluation times and high vaporization temperatures. In this case, the formation of longer-chain oligomerized compounds may explain the variation in conversion values, even though no reaction products were detected. Additionally, the fouling mechanism, which involves the coverage of the catalyst surface by oligomerized compounds, could account for the observed loss of activity. Similar findings have been reported in the literature regarding aqueous phase reforming (APR) studies involving aromatic molecules [55,61]. A recent study by Pipitone et al. [55] suggests the phenolic oligomers to be one of the primary causes of the deactivation of Pt/C catalysts in APR involving lignin-derived hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) water. Their research indicated that removing the phenolic compounds from the treated HTL water improved both the activity and stability of the catalyst. To our knowledge, phenol aqueous phase reforming has not been tested under plug-flow conditions. Instead, a few publications have focused on phenol APR in batch operation [40,42]. For example, Yan et al. [42] conducted a series of phenol reforming experiments in batch mode, utilizing various phenol concentrations, pressures, and temperatures. They used Ni/ZSM-5–25 as a catalyst, achieving phenol conversions that varied between 60 % and 100 %, which were significantly higher than those reported in this work. The optimal conditions were found at 49 bar and 240 °C, with an initial phenol concentration of 0.2 mol/L, resulting in a phenol conversion of 92 %. Additionally, they reported hydrogen selectivity of 80 % and alkane selectivity of 20 %. However, the authors did not specify which hydrocarbon products were formed, nor did they mention any liquid product formation. Notably, the product selectivity towards the targeted hydrogen was much better compared to the findings of this study, a difference that can be partially attributed to the longer reaction times associated with batch operations. 3.2.4 4-methylcatechol 4-methylcatechol was the second oxygenated aromatic selected for this study, and, to our knowledge, its reactivity for aqueous phase reforming has not been studied previously. The calculated product yields and carbon balance for APR of 4-methylcatechol over tested catalysts are shown in Fig. 9. Similar to the experiments with acetic acid and phenol, rapid catalyst deactivation was observed with 4-methylcatechol. As a result, the product composition was compared at TOS 30 min. Across all tested catalysts, the main gaseous products were H2 and/or CO2, while the liquid samples contained p-cresol, m-cresol, and unreacted 4-methylcatechol. See Fig. 10 for the quantified amount of produced cresols. The product composition was found to be remarkably different between noble and base metal catalysts, as well as between Cu- and Co-doped nickel catalysts. In the case of the Pt catalyst, which exhibited the highest initial conversion of 4-methylcatechol (∼30 %), the hydrogen yield was only 0.1 %, with the main reaction products being CO2 (Y(CO2)= 0.4 %) and cresols (Y(liq. products)= 1.0 %). This suggests parallel reforming reactions (Eq. 15) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO, Eq. 16), where the former produces hydrogen that is subsequently used in the formation of liquid products. For NiCo/ZrO2, the HDO reaction of 4-methylcatechol seemed to dominate over reforming, particularly in the initial phase of the experiment. For the Co-doped nickel catalyst, the hydrogen yield was 1.5 %, the yield of produced liquids totaled 3.3 %, and the CO2 yield was 0.1 %. The product composition between the two NiCu-catalysts differed significantly, making it challenging to draw conclusions about the prevailing reactions for this metal combination. Moreover, the rapid deactivation of the catalyst obscured its intrinsic behavior. NiCu/γ-Al2O3 produced mostly hydrogen with a yield of 0.3 % and trace amounts of CO2, while NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 exhibited higher hydrogen yield (Y(H2)= 1.3 %), but only small amounts of liquid products were formed (Y(liq. products)= 0.1 %). Full reforming of 4-methylcatechol (15) Image 12 Hydrodeoxygenation of 4-methylcatechol (16) Image 13 As said, Pt/AC demonstrated the highest initial conversion of 30 % for 4-methylcatechol but lost half of the activity in 60 min TOS. Doped nickel catalysts had good initial conversion of up to 20 %, but a significant drop in conversion after 30 min occurred, resulting in almost complete deactivation of the nickel catalysts. The carbon balance only closed between 85 % and 89 % at TOS 30 min for nickel catalysts. Based on the catalyst characterizations, it was observed that the fast deactivation was largely accounted for by carbon accumulation on the catalyst surface: the amount of carbon per sample was 7–10 wt%, covering almost completely the missing carbon from the balance. This also explains the significant drop in the catalyst activity as the active sites were most likely covered by carbonaceous species (coke). Regarding commercial Pt, the carbon balance closure was 72 % for the same sampling time, but due to activated carbon support, elemental analysis for carbon deposits could not be performed with Pt catalyst. However, activated carbon materials possess a high affinity towards condensation reactions with phenolic compounds, including catechols [55,62]. In addition, micropores are known for their coking capability, which can lead to a very fast pore filling with coke also supporting the observed behavior of the platinum catalyst when tested with 4-methylcatechol. To the best of our knowledge, the APR of 4-methylcatechol has not been previously reported. However, other oxygenated aromatics have been studied to a some extent. For instance, Pipitone et al. [56] investigated several model compounds derived from various sources of the post-HTL aqueous phase of lignocellulosic feed, including guaiacol. In their research, the APR experiments were conducted in batch operations at different temperatures ranging from 230 to 270 °C using a platinum catalyst. The highest carbon-to-gas conversion of 7 % was achieved at 270 °C. With guaiacol, the primary gaseous product formed was methane, which likely resulted from the cleavage of the ether group, while catechol was produced as a liquid product. In another study, Arandia et al. [37] examined the APR of 5 wt% catechol-water mixture at 230 °C and 32 bar over various monometallic nickel catalysts. Their results indicated that the main gaseous product was hydrogen, with similar yields to those obtained in the present work. The catechol conversion was around 8–9 % after 3 h of TOS. Additionally, liquid products were mentioned as forming, but they were not identified in their study. 3.3 Addressing causes for catalyst deactivation A clear distinction was seen in the stability of platinum and nickel catalysts in the APR experiments. Out of the tested model compound solutions, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol deactivated the nickel catalysts within 60 min time-on-stream. In case of methanol, there was no clear sign of catalyst deactivation with neither nickel nor platinum catalysts. Commercial platinum catalyst showed reasonably stable conversion with acetic acid and methanol, whereas no activity was seen in the phenol APR over Pt catalyst. For 4-methylcatechol and Pt, a reasonably high initial conversion was detected but the activity dropped over 50 % within 60 min. In regard to APR, catalyst deactivation can be attributed to the changes in the support morphology and/or in active metal, including metal leaching, loss of active surface area due to sintering or fouling, or changes in oxidation state [20]. In order to assess the weight of these changes on the activity loss, the spent catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, XRD, TEM, and ICP-OES, and the results were compared against fresh samples. 3.3.1 Morphological changes The results from N2 physisorption, i.e. BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter, which were used to evaluate changes in the catalyst surface morphology, are given in Table 3. The most significant alterations in surface properties were observed with catalysts tested for 4-methylcatechol APR. For example, the BET surface areas of the doped Ni-catalysts decreased by around 14–17 %, while for the Pt catalyst, the decrease was nearly 44 %. This change can be attributed to the surface coverage and/or pore filling with carbonaceous deposits (coke) during the reaction. It is worth noting that in the case of Pt/AC, there was no indication of mesopore blocking or decrease in their size. Similarly, no clear evidence of pore blockage or surface coverage was observed with the nickel catalyst and the second oxygenated aromatic, phenol, according to N2 physisorption. For platinum, the surface area after APR of phenol decreased from 915 m2/g to 757 m2/g (i.e., 17 %), indicating possible surface coverage by carbonaceous species. NiCo/ZrO2 and NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 showed no major changes in surface properties after experimenting with methanol or phenol. For these catalysts, the specific surface areas slightly increased after the experiment with acetic acid, likely due to metal leaching that exposed the surface of the catalyst support. In the case of the platinum catalyst, the properties remained unchanged after experiments with acetic acid, with only a slight decrease in surface area observed with methanol experiments. The most significant decrease in surface area and pore volume was observed after methanol APR with NiCu/γ-Al2O3, where the BET surface area decreased from 184 m2/g to 18 m2/g. In addition, for the same sample, the mean pore volume decreased from 0.53 cm3/g to 0.09 cm3/g. Similar observations were made for γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts tested with other model compounds. The decrease in surface properties was attributed to the phase change of γ-Al2O3 to boehmite (γ-Al(O)OH), as verified by XRD analysis (see Fig. 14). However, the NiCu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst tested with methanol was found to maintain activity despite the phase change, hence the exclusion of the phase change as a cause of deactivation, instead indicating a physical morphology change in the catalyst. Interestingly, there was no evidence of a phase change to boehmite with the γ-Al2O3-supported catalyst tested with 4-methylcatechol. Similar observations have been reported by Arandia et al. [37] when testing APR of the hydrophilic fraction of bio-oil with several monometallic nickel catalysts. According to the findings of this work, a hypothesis was formulated that dissolved Ni and promoters could form surface complexes with 4-methylcatechol, inhibiting dissolution and protonation of alumina, leading to the distinctive behavior observed with the 4-methylcatechol-mixture [63]. 3.3.2 Catalyst fouling Catalyst coking is reported as one of the deactivation mechanisms in some APR studies [14,27,62]. Fig. 11 displays the amount of carbon buildup on the catalyst surface measured by elemental analysis. To compare the carbon increase in the used nickel samples, calcined catalysts were used as a reference point. The calcined catalyst samples contained a small amount of residual carbon (0.4 wt%), likely originating from some graphitic carbon resulting from the support synthesis. The measured values are provided for doped Ni catalysts as the method was not applicable for active carbon-supported Pt catalysts due to reaching the limit of quantification. However, the decrease in BET surface area with platinum tested for phenol and 4-methylcatechol APR indicates carbon accumulation over the active metal, see Table 3. As mentioned previously, there was evidence of oligomerization of the phenolic compounds that was observed in the liquid sample analysis. These oligomerized compounds have high affinity to deposit on the active sites, thus causing catalyst deactivation [62,64]. Additionally, microporous materials are known to promote fouling in hydrothermal conditions, which could also explain the slight decrease in surface areas in the Pt/AC samples. Out of the model compound solutions, the carbon formation was most noticeable with nickel catalysts tested with 4-methylcatechol. The measured carbon content ranged between 7–10 wt% for all doped Ni catalysts, aligning with the findings of N2 physisorption and the decrease in surface areas (refer to Table 3). TEM images confirmed clear carbon deposits, with two types of coke structures, i.e. amorphous coke and presenting seemingly crystalline arrangement over the catalyst surfaces around the metal oxide nanoparticles. As for example, refer to Fig. 12 of the spent NiCo/ZrO2 catalyst after experimenting with 4-methylcatechol. Note that the spacing between the planes are in the range of 0.8 nm, which is closed to graphene oxide (0.74 nm) [65], whose interlayer spacing is known to be varied from 0.74 nm to 1.3 nm by the presence of bridging organic functions [65]. This is supported by the observation of a small peak at 12° [65] in the XRD diffractogram (see Fig. 15), characteristic of graphene oxide. These carbon deposits could be attributed to the deactivation of the catalysts during the APR of 4-methylcatechol. More TEM images can be found from Supplementary material, Section 5. The elemental carbon on samples tested with methanol was found to be lower than that of the fresh catalyst. This most likely resulted from the decrease in weight of the catalyst after reduction. For nickel catalysts tested with phenol, and acetic acid, the carbon increase was less than 2.0 wt% compared to the fresh sample. The increase in the carbon content of catalysts tested with phenol, acetic acid, and methanol was much lower compared to samples tested with 4-methylcatechol, which indicated that the catalyst deactivation must have been a combination of different deactivation mechanisms, including fouling, for the other three model compounds. 3.3.3 Changes in particle size The changes in particle size are often associated with particle growth resulting from metal sintering or leaching, which can lead to a decrease in particle sizes. Table 3 shows the average crystal sizes (XRD) and particle size (TEM) for both support and active metals in the nickel catalysts. For the spent samples tested for APR of acetic acid, analyses were not conducted due to extensive metal leaching, over 80 %, as shown in Table 4. NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 showed no critical change in NiCu(0) crystal size in the samples tested with any of the model compound solutions. TEM confirmed the stability of the metal oxide particles for the tested samples. On the other hand, NiCu/γ-Al2O3 showed a severe growth in particle size, especially after methanol APR, observed in TEM. XRD revealed that γ-Al2O3 converted to γ-Al(O)OH (support crystal size increased from 3–4 nm up to 40 nm) and a slight increase of NiCu(0) crystal size (from 17–18 nm to 23–40 nm). In case of the phenolic compounds, there was an indication of NiCu(0) crystal size growth with Al2O3-supported nickel catalysts according to XRD, especially for the sample tested for APR of 4-methylcatechol, where the metal alloy crystal size doubled from the original value of the reduced sample. These findings were consistent with the TEM analysis. Note that the XRD analysis of the ZrO2-supported samples proved to be rather challenging due to overlapping peaks and small, noisy signal (Fig. 15). In these samples, leaching of the active metals was up to 30 % with phenolic compounds, further complicating the analysis. For Co-doped nickel tested for methanol APR, there was no indication of the change in the crystal sizes (support or active metal), whereas, for phenol and 4-methylcatechol, the NiCo(0) crystal size had slightly increased from the original value, being more pronounced with catalysts tested for 4-methylcatechol APR. XRD and TEM analyses confirmed the stability of the metal oxide support (ZrO2), with no change in the crystal size. 3.3.4 Leaching and re-oxidation Nickel-based materials are known for their sensitivity to re-oxidation, especially by acidic solution [66]. In this study, XRD analyses showed no oxidation of crystalline phases in the spent nickel samples. This suggests that the oxidation of NiM clusters is not the main cause of deactivation, but rather remains a surface phenomenon that results in the release of additional hydrogen gas during the experiment (Fig. 3A). In addition, some studies have reported undesirable metal leaching during APR [12,37]. The table below shows the percentage of metal loss for each model compound per studied catalyst determined by ICP-OES (Table 4). Due to dilution of the Pt catalyst with inert silicon carbide, the ICP analysis was conducted by analyzing the noble metal residues from the liquid samples. The Pt levels in those solutions were lower than the detection limit (<1 %, see Supplementary material, Section 3.4.2.3 for more information on the liquid sample analysis). In contrast, leaching was found to be a primary cause of catalyst deactivation with doped nickel catalysts, and the metal loss was more significant with more acidic solutions. The pH of the prepared solutions decreased in the following order: methanol (pH 6.7) > phenol (pH 4.1) > 4-methylcatechol (pH 3.9) > acetic acid (pH 2.5). The most severe metal leaching was observed in the experiments with acetic acid, where more than 80 % of the original amount of impregnated nickel was lost (Table 4). Among the tested catalysts, NiCu/CeO2-ZrO2 was found to be the most resistant, with no change in the content of nickel (or promoter) observed after APR of phenol or methanol. This behavior can be related to the larger particle size of NiM on this catalyst and/or stronger support-metal interactions between CeO2-ZrO2 and active metals. Conversely, NiCo/ZrO2 and NiCu/γ-Al2O3 were found to be the least stable, with metal loss observed with all tested model compounds, even with methanol, which had almost a neutral pH. Furthermore, the operating conditions also affected the concentration of promoters, Cu and Co, especially cobalt, which decreased to a greater extent than copper in the experiments. This could be due to the higher solubility of cobalt under the applied conditions compared to copper. Regarding oxide supports, acidic solutions have been reported to increase the solubility of the support itself, including alumina [28], which promotes metal loss from the catalyst bed (loss of catalyst debris, separation of Ni/Co/Cu particles from the oxide). In addition, the phase change of γ-alumina to boehmite was expected to contribute to the metal leaching to some extent as it enables particle migration due to support structure collapse. 4 Conclusions The study investigated the catalytic aqueous phase reforming (APR) of four representative compounds: methanol, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol for hydrogen production. These compounds were selected based on their presence in water derived from black liquor HTL, aiming to explore the potential for valorizing aqueous effluents in innovative biorefinery concepts. Due to limited literature on the APR of phenolic compounds, several catalyst combinations that have shown promise with commonly studied compounds, including alcohols and sugars, were investigated. Three in-house prepared, Cu- or Co-doped nickel catalyst and one commercial Pt catalyst were tested in a fixed-bed reactor at 230 °C and 32 bar with all four model compound mixtures. The Pt catalyst demonstrated better stability under the applied conditions compared to Cu- or Co-doped nickel catalysts. The Pt/AC catalyst exhibited stable and reasonably high conversion with methanol and acetic acid throughout the experimental period. However, platinum showed no activity with the phenol mixture, and a rapid deactivation was observed when platinum was tested with 4-methylcatechol. The loss of activity was attributed to carbon depositions. Severe catalyst deactivation was also observed with the doped nickel catalysts, especially when tested with acetic acid and phenolic compounds. The catalyst deactivation under phenolic solutions was attributed to particle sintering and carbon depositions. On the other hand, for catalysts tested with acetic acid, the deactivation was attributed to extreme leaching (>80 %) of active metals. The product composition varied depending on the tested model compound and catalyst. For methanol, the main reaction products were H2 and CO2, with the NiCu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrating the highest selectivity for H2 production, as no side products were detected. Under the same conditions, Co-doped nickel also favored hydrogenation reactions in methanol APR, resulting in reasonable formation of CH4, thereby lowering the H2 production. The activity and hydrogen yield were in same range for platinum catalyst as it was with in-house made nickel catalyst. Notably, the platinum catalysts, when tested with compounds other than methanol, showed lower hydrogen yield compared to doped nickel catalysts. Furthermore, in the case of acetic acid, only the Pt catalyst maintained stable activity over the three-hour experiment, predominantly favoring decarboxylation reaction under the applied conditions. As for the phenol and 4-methylcatechol, the main products with hydrodeoxygenated (4-methylcatechol) or hydrogenated (phenol) liquid products, with lesser favourability to H2 or CO2 formation. Out of the tested catalysts, NiCo/ZrO2 showed the best hydrogen yield with aromatic compounds. The results of this study will contribute to the development of APR catalysts for real process waters by enhancing the understanding of how different compounds and conditions impact catalyst behavior. Two catalysts, NiCo/ZrO2 and Pt/AC, were identified as promising candidates for further studies. NiCo/ZrO2 showed higher intrinsic activity towards reforming aromatic structures, while the stability of Pt/AC under the applied conditions was noted. Nonetheless, improvements are required in the stability of Ni-based catalysts and the selectivity of Pt-based catalysts towards targeted H2 production. In addition, investigating the synergetic effect of multicomponent systems, such as alcohol and aromatic combinations, is recommended for future work. coredata.dc:description: The aqueous phase reforming of methanol, acetic acid, phenol, and 4-methylcatechol was studied to evaluate the potential of using process water from hydrothermal liquefaction of black liquor for hydrogen production. Various catalysts, including Cu- or Co-doped nickel and commercial Pt/AC, were tested under plug-flow conditions (230 °C, 32 bar). The platinum catalyst showed superior stability, maintaining high conversion with methanol and acetic acid. However, it showed no activity with phenol and deactivated rapidly when exposed to 4-methylcatechol. Doped nickel catalysts experienced severe deactivation, particularly with acetic acid and phenolic compounds. While nickel catalyst deactivated in the presence of acetic acid, Pt showed stable conversion but favored decarboxylation reaction. APR of methanol primarily produced H2 and CO2, with NiCu/γ-Al2O3 being the most selective for H2. Co-doped nickel favored hydrogenation, forming CH4 and thus reducing H2 yield. APR of phenol and 4-methylcatechol produced H2, CO2, and hydrodeoxygenated or hydrogenated liquid products.
